title: Which country will win the 2018 FIFA World Cup?
preds: Jeez, all that video refereeing and still total rubbish of calls. 1) Greizmann dived and, if anything, should have been given a yellow. Definitely not a FK. 2) When a ball hits your hand from less than a meter away, there is no way your handball could be intentional - it's just not possible physiologically. Definitely not a PK. France is full of great talent but a better team lost today.
Hope I'm wrong about this, because like many people I love underdogs.  There is, however, a reason they're called that.
Hedging, as my brier score has not been fairing well
London will become so distracted by Trump Derangement symptoms that they "WILL" Croatia to protest by taking a knee.

60-40 to 75-25.  Viva le Macronys!  Does that mean UK's PM Theresa May will be next to go? I mean seriously, what is going on? Kim Fatty III gets a meeting, Ethiopia & Eritrea peace, Roger Federer out of Wimbledon. Trumpet meeting a committed adversary.  Might be a good upset, wish my other contrary bets had worked out with luck though.

Happy to diverge from the 538 forecast here, now that it is a simple "who will win this one game"? In my (non-expert) opinion, France have been playing a little under, and Croatia somewhat above, the expectations for these teams coming in to the tournament.  On that basis, I think 538 slightly overweights the team performances prior to the tournament. Betting markets are generally sitting at about 67% France to 33% Croatia.  Were I a betting man, I'd be more than happy to put a heavy bet on Croatia at that price! On the other hand, I need to be aware of my own biases, which are twofold:
a)  France put in an unconvincing performance against Australia, and part of me feels "they don't deserve to be in the final".
b)  Compared to the consensus trend, a win for France will (probably) be a small win for me in Accuracy, but a win for "Another country" (which I have always had north of 20%, and the consensus had below 10% until just before the round of 16) will be a big win for me in Accuracy.  So I REALLY would like a win for Croatia!
This is a purely personal call. America loves an underdog. Let's go Hrvatska!

France/Croatia final - 538 has this as a 59/41 split in favor of the French, but I think Croatia's legs could easily come into play going into this final having played 360 minutes in 10 days. I'm giving France a greater edge for that reason.
Croatia is tired but England has no game

Will Croatia's star Modric be distracted with the corruption scandal news? (Even foreignPolicy.com had an article about how Croatia hates it's own team.)
Or will the Poms struggle under self-imposed pressure? Or will it drive them to 'bring it home' (thanks for @rwd member, forget the proper username) Edge to FRA anyway for extra day rest. 
Why ENG v CRO game is starting at 9PM is beyond me. If you're a football fan in the UK you'll stay up and watch it anyway, why risk losing with messed up body clock?  Should be higher to France but have been for them from the start. Macron V May will be interesting and May isn't having a good time right now. Thought ENG could really provide a morale boost in the Brexit mess.  Edit: found @rwd5035 name  Thurs12July: Sincere condolences to the Poms, have to wait another 4 years for the chance to be able to say that football is coming home. ;-P
538 + betting markets, which put more weight on France. https://www.oddschecker.com/football/world-cup/winner
Based on 538, but I've bumped up France because its team will have had an extra day of rest.  (I wonder if that's already been figured in to 538's forecast?)

Scandal involving Croatia's star Luka Modric and a teammate and a major Croatian football magnate have been kept quiet but are likely to keep the small-market team from advancing against England... link here https://www.dw.com/en/football-scandal-casts-shadow-on-croatias-summer-fairy-tale/a-44559779

Back-engineering the model at FiveThirtyEight (FRA 55%; ENG 27%; CRO 18%) ... If Croatia win tonight (43%), then they have a 41% chance of beating France.  [0.43 * 0.41 = 0.18]
If England win tonight (57%), then they have a 47% chance of beating France.  [0.57 * 0.47 = 0.27] To my inexpert eye, those odds seem about right.  I might nudge the English chances against France and Croatia up a bit (given the preponderance of goals scored from set play in the last few weeks - including last night - which the English are dominating at). By my thoughts ...
If Croatia win tonight (??40%), then they have a 41% chance of beating France.  [0.40 * 0.41 = 0.16]
If England win tonight (??60%), then they have a ??55% chance of beating France.  [0.60 * 0.55 = 0.33] So I have: FRA 51%; ENG 33%; CRO 16%.
Although france’s win wasn’t decisive I believe they are the strongest side left.
The game is not over but Belgium's chances look slim (1:0)
England and Croatia are in with a chance. I think it will be between Belgium and England and I give Belgium a slight edge.
OK this is a bit biased, but I do have high hopes for France!
Had to change from Spain to Belgium - bevor semi finals

I would predict an England Vs France final, based on the quarter final performance. Unlikely to be Croatia to win as they seem the weakest team - having only got through on penalties twice in a row. If Belgium beat France, they're in with a shot, but that's a challenge.

Just another Euro Cup. Belgium and France stayed longer in 2016:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016

Should really give Russia some crumbs given there have been surprise upsets. Hopefully it's France v England or Croatia. I really shouldn't be France 50% but what the heck.  If Russia win it's going to be nuts. Did someone put 100% on Russia?

By demonstrated play so far, it ought to be a winner of FRA-BEL semi. But that in itself feels like 50:50 (slight edge to BEL for more experience?) and it is nearly always 50:50 in the final, even if SWE somehow makes it. So only a slight bias toward stronger teams. Discounting Russia completely, of course.

Another bites the dust. The best team in the tournament, Brazil, goes out, France and Belgium advance. France is better than Belgium but that game is going to be weird. Increases the chances that football is coming home.
Belgium have beaten Brazil and now have to face France in a semi-final. We will know the other semifinalists tomorrow.
Belgium beats Brazil. I split their 20% between France and Belgium.
France is in the semi-final, will meet the winner of Brazil vs Belgium there.

Did Brazil's Neymar really hurt his ankle or just a stunt? If so it'd be better by now right?   1392 from 517 Brazil on 36% and other at 29. France declining to 23. Belgium is 14. Other is UK, Croatia and the cheatin' Russkis.  Fingers crossed Croatia beat Russia!
France ranked #1 now, see if they can beat Brazil.  England break the penalty shootout hoodoo.
Brazil and France will be competiting against each other. Will update to 100% when the results of that match is concluded
Sweden wins against Switzerland, so Switzerland's 4% go to "Another country".

Brazil 3/1, France 17/4, Belgium 13/2, Croatia 13/2, England 7/1, Uruguay 16/1, Colombia 22/1, Russia 22/1, Switzerland 35/1 and Sweden 50/1. https://www.oddschecker.com/football/world-cup/winner If Switzerland doesn't win its Round of 16 match today, its 4% will shift to "Another Country". Looking ahead, Brazil, France, Belgium (and Uruguay) are in the tougher half of the draw, while Russia/Croatia are bracketed with Switzerland/Sweden and England/Colombia and seem to have an easier path to the final.

Brazil vs Crotia? Nooooa! Well as long as it's not Russia.  Belgium beating Brazil would be amazing though. And Colombia over England would be funny.  For all we know it could be the Swiss. Flying right under the radar!

Huh - France's probability on 538 went DOWN from 16% yesterday to 15% today.  They must be sitting extremely close to 15.5%.  Alternatively, the model must favour France's ability to beat [a Japan who had beaten Brazil] more highly than France's ability to beat [Brazil].
After several of the most established teams have already been knocked out, it is looking more likely that an outsider will surprise the world and win.
On Brazil reaching the quarter finals.
Spain lost to Russia, Denmark lost to Croatia, Brazil won against Mexico and all winners get the probability mass of the losers.

http://www.eloratings.net/
Uruguay; Russia; France; Croatia; Brazil; Mexico; Switzerland; Sweden; Belgium; Japan; England; Colombia
 weightings infavor of ranked teams

https://www.oddschecker.com/au/soccer/world-cup/winner First Germany, then Spain. Tonight Brazil plays Mexico - surely not another shock result? Probabilities above are exactly according to https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-world-cup-predictions/?ex_cid=rrpromo For comparison, see https://www.oddschecker.com/football/world-cup/winner where Brazil and France are equal favorites at 4/1
England and Croatia are next at 6/1, followed by Belgium at 13/2. 
After these five come Uruguay 15/1, Russia and Colombia at 20/1, and the rest - Switzerland 40/1, Sweden and Mexico 50/1, Japan 250/1.
Some teams from the list have already been eliminated, while there is now a higher likelihood of 'Another country' winning given the way the draw has played out.

How good are the goalies of Croatia and Russia? If the goalies are going to be theatrical and dive to the ground, why kick there? I know coaches teach players it's their best odds though, but rarely has a goalie stayed standing. Kick to the upper corners!  Giving Spain's 21% to 'Another country' and topping up France.
A bit late in updating the scores!

I used a decision tree for my forecast. I started my calculation before the match Croatia vs. Denmark. So Brazil (four possible upcoming games) has a lower probabilty to win compared to France (three possible upcoming games).
The odds are self-made. Most of them are even or close to (cause you could already see underdogs playing well in round of 16). And odds for the final are always even to simplify the operation and because the final game can't be compared to the previous ones in terms of predictability IMO.
de Gea makes 0 saves and fails to stop any of 5 penalty kicks.

Making some updates after Spain's loss to Russia opens up the right side of the bracket. Croatia, England and Uruguay offer the best opportunities for other countries to win the World Cup. Odds for Belgium, Spain and France all increase because they'd have favorable matchups in the final if they got there. Added some percentages for Russia finally, simply because they are in the QF now and have a shot. Switzerland get a bit of a boost too since they're on the right side.

This Spain was not going anywhere anyway. Realistically, it's down to six teams. Sweden/Croatia/England vs Brazil/France/Belgium, i.e. roughly 50:50 between "Another country" and the rest of the bins.
Redistribution of probabilities after Spain's exit.
The winning team get the probability mass of the losing team. Quick and simple.

There are now a 'difficult path' and an 'easy path' to the final and the winner of the difficult path branch should not be more than a 2/3 favorite. So Belgium+Brazil+France+Uruguay(Another) = 65 and England(Another)+Spain = 35. Right now Brazil and France are joint favorites with about 20% each so 25 to Belgium and Uruguay, 15 to England and 20 to Spain. I fancy Belgium over Uruguay, but not by much, so I allocate 15 and 10 respectively leaving 25 for Another country (10 Uru + 15 Eng). I fancy Belgium over Spain outright, but being part of the easy branch gives Spain the edge.

BRA|FRA vs SPA|ENG. Or Belgium.  Brazil is most hungry but France are doing quite well and have some good stars.  Comes down to refs and draw (and weather at those places). And selections/injuries - do they go hard and win or rest the stars for the finals?
6 listed sides remain (2 assured spots for the final 8), along with 8 unlisted sides (3 assured spots for the final 8). Referees do not seem to favor star sides and players ... so far.

BTW, between the six finalists of the last World, Euro and America Cups, only one remains in the tournament - France. France has also just overcome Spain in ELO ratings, taking a #2 spot after #1 Brazil.

Only one spot in the final for either France, Brazil, Belgium, Portugal or Uruguay. The second spot in the final is open for Spain, England, Croatia, Swden, Russia. Seems that who ever wins the French half of the bracket would be heavily favored in the final ...  still, it will only be a single match, with both sides on a winning streak....
Shifting Argentina's 5% to France. Probabilities will change after practically every match from now on.

Step 2: Updating with 538's model [1].
My baseline: each country in the finals has an equal chance of making it, i.e. 6.25%. Adjusting based on the group stage and some intuition based on team strength.
Adjusting based on 538 model. Country: my initial prediction vs 538 prediction --> updated prediction
Uruguay: 8%, 3% --> 5%
Russia: 7%, 1% --> 4%
Spain: 6%, 20% --> 13%
Portugal: 6%, 5% --> 6%
France: 7%, 8% --> 7%
Denmark: 4%, 1% --> 3%
Croatia: 8%, 6% --> 7%
Argentina: 6%, 5% --> 6%
Brazil: 8%, 25% --> 17%
Switzerland: 6%, 3% --> 4%
Sweden: 6%, 3% --> 4%
Mexico: 6%, 0% --> 3%
England: 7%, 9% --> 8%
Belgium: 7%, 9% --> 8%
Group H (Japan/Colombia/Senegal): 8%, 1%, 5%. All in all, 538's model seems to have used information better than what I did so that they conclude with a much higher probability on Spain and Brazil making it. Maybe the FIFA world ranking or prior worldcup performance? [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-world-cup-predictions/
PS: I forgot Switzerland and Argentina in my last forecast, so they received my baseline of 6% without further update.

My baseline: each country in the finals has an equal chance of making it, i.e. 6.25%. Adjusting based on the group stage and some intuition based on team strength. Uruguay: Won all games, gets 8%.
Russia: Won 2/3, host bonus, 7%.
Spain: Won 1/3, still I think strong team, 6%.
Portugal: Won 1/3, still I think strong team, 6%.
France: Won 2/3, 7%.
Denmark: Won 1/3, 4%.
Croatia: Won 3/3, 8%.
Brazil: Won 2/3, strong team, 8%.
Sweden: Won 2/3, 6%.
Mexico: Won 2/3, 6%.
England: Won 2/2, 7%.
Belgium: Won 2/2, 7%.
Group H (Japan/Colombia/Senegal): not decided yet, I give this group 8%.

I have made some changes following Germany's surprise elimination from the World Cup. Spain gets an increase because they would have been on the same side of Germany had the Germans advanced in 1st. Other countries, Switzerland and Belgium also get a boost now, as the bottom half of the right side (F1, E2, G2, H1) is going to be wide open pending Brazil winning Group E. Whoever is in that quarter of the bracket will have a realistic chance of getting to the semifinal. Also, whoever finishes 2nd out of England and Belgium will likely be the odds on favorite for a semifinal berth in this section, as such their chances increase a bit with Germany's elimination.

Can't believe Germany is out, but don't care given they were milking and diving so much - they actually did the impossible and made Italy seem professional, disciplined, sportsmanlike and not cheats at all (in 2010 & 2014). Glad Italy didn't make it in 2018.   Once this is over I can go back to not giving a shit about soccer and watch real diving at the pool.

Brazil have become the clear favorite, Spain, Belgium, Portugal, and France are all in good position. I have been impressed by Mexico, though don't rate their chances to win the competition simply because of how reliant on the counter they are. England and Uruguay look good for the other countries, and think they have the talent to pull it out given how well they have played so far.

Not that I assume that Nate et al know more about soccer than the pundits, but because they know their stuff about breaking down the probabilities for each game's outcome, and translating that into a probability for the tournament as a whole.
Taking 5 off Spain to give to Portugal. Seems like Germany is favourite and Brazil are very hungry. France is very close.  Will be interesting to see how England go.
Bwahahaha am betting on Portugal beating Spain. For some reason, Spain fired their head coach right before the tournament started and I can't imagine that that's good for the players' spirits.

Updating my forecast because SPAIN'S MANAGER GOT SACKED!!!!!!! This is an incredibly drastic move and suggests deep turmoil behind the scenes. I've redistributed to France because their squad is both well rounded and star studded. https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44467548

http://www.businessinsider.com/world-cup-predictions-pick-to-win-it-all-goldman-sachs-ai-model-2018-6 The firm used machine learning to run 200,000 models, mining data on team and individual player attributes, to help forecast specific match scores. Goldman then simulated 1 million variations of the tournament to calculate the probability of advancement for each squad. Here are the key takeaways from Goldman's data: Brazil is expected to win its sixth World Cup title, defeating Germany in the final by an unrounded score of 1.70 to 1.41 While France has better overall odds of lifting the trophy than Germany, its expected meeting with Brazil in the semifinals has it falling short of the title match England is expected to make it to the quarterfinal stage, where Goldman says it will lose to Germany Spain and Argentina are forecast to underperform, both losing in the quarterfinals Russia isn't expected to make it out of the group stage, despite its role as tournament host Saudi Arabia is deemed the surprise team that advances out of the group stage, ahead of Russia
Messi for Argentina, and Messi predicts Belgium as possibility. Germany and Brazil as the usual suspects.

Re-ran model with updated ELO scores following recent friendlies. Also removed my non-model adjustment for Russia: they didn't get past the semis once in 2,500 sims: surely any advantage they have (either above board or otherwise) won't turn a <1% chance of reaching the semis into a >0% chance of winning it. Will it? Will it?! Big losers here are Germany (-5%), with Brazil (+2%) and France (+2%) gaining.

Just wanted to record my first guess. This is based on very little information and what my estimated base rate is. Will update my forecast soon after I've done more research.

My favorites to win the tournament is Germany due to the amount of talent in their squad in every position they have major key players. There midfield is without a doubt the strongest going into the world cup.
Putin says Spain is most likely to win. Is he a superforecaster? I am not sure he is aware that there is a very good chance that Spain will play Russia in 1/8th.
Germany have a strong team and a very analytical backstage that give then a great vantage agains the other teams
The Belgian team is loaded with talent and the manager has experience with most of the players on the team.

Lade my top Of the head estimate from group stage to winner. Put 50% for final teams and a 60/40 split between them, 25% chance that either of the semi finalists will take the win and 25% that either of the quarter finalists will find glory. Will update with better estimates shortly.

Recent revelations from disgraced ex-UEFA boss Mickey Platini about 1998 Brazil-France fix so as not to meet until final game casts shadow over Bleus and Brazil with superstar Neymar and others on talented side likely unable to overcome the trauma they were dealt by the 0-6 drubbing in Rio at the hands of Low's German team.

Same model as my previous forecast, updated with new ELOs following friendly matches. Again, the model forecasts 0% chance for Russia but I've manually increased to 1%, taking 1% from "Other". There's just something strange about Russia...

Belgium and Brazil both have a good team but still less so then Germany who has the best team and the most experience. Never count out Spain though or a other random country. I don't see Argentina winning this world cup they depend to much on a sup par messi.
Brazil won't get far with Dani Alves out and Neymar too rich and egotistical to be a team leader. An African side could surprise.
Spain and Germany are actually the dominating Teams. Other Teams have just Outsider chances.
Germany, Brazil, Argentina and Uraguay have won 13 World Cups to 3 for the rest of the field.

Germany always has a fair chance of winning, its very unlikely that a southern hemisphere country wins in a northern hemisphere tournament (look at the stats) hence my relative low probabilities on Arg. and Brazil. Portugal and Belgium could win it, especially Belgium has a cracking team with stars. Russia as the home nation is a possibility and other countries need to get a relaive high % as well.

• Argentina does not stand a chance without Messi
• Brazil, though stronger than in 2014, still has not the depth in the team to succeed. 
• Spain comes in strong (especially judging after the last two games) 
• France's positive development is uncanny. I expect at least the 1/4 
• Germany's position in the world of football cannot be denied. Don't be mislead by the last game against Brazil featuring the weakest of their goalkeepers, and a team that has not been playing together before. Löw still needs to decide which of the players are not going and the depth of this team might be the strongest with only Spain and France coming close.
• other teams such as Portugal and Belgium might have a minor chance to succeed. If either meets any strong team (any of the above) from the 1/4 up, they will not succeed.

Germans world cup-winning formula is still in place, but only with much better players. Remember when we thought Mario Goetze was amazing for his strike in the finals? Yeah, they have much better players on the squad now. Many of their players belong to the second strongest club in the world: Bayern Munich.  France has a chance to get to the finals with their youthful talent, and no slouch for a skipper. However, Germany's stuff is just better than everyone else's.

Simulated 2,500 times using logistic model based on ELO (http://www.eloratings.net/) calibrated to last 3 World Cups. This method gave 0% chance for Russia but suspect they will enjoy more home advantage than previous hosts so increased to 1% (non-model adjustment). Brazil, Germany and Spain (in that order) are the strongest teams in the tournament, followed by a reasonably close group. Assuming they win their groups: Germany will avoid any other top 6 team (Brazil, Spain, Argentina, France, Portugal) until at least the semis. QF against (most likely) either England or Belgium will be tricky. Brazil's 2nd round match (most likely Mexico) and QF (most likely either England or Belgium) will both be tricky. Spain will secure a straightforward 2nd round opponent (most likely Russia) and most likely have a tricky but winnable QF against Argentina.
Updating to give Spain a higher % after their match V Argentina as it was particularly impressive. I have also cut some % off France for their defeat against Columbia.
Argentina suffered a great defeat playing Spain today. Many saw it as cutting its world cup chances.

A forecast made only with my personal knowledge of the sport.

Key Players in the Game Right Now The 2017 FIFA top 24 players in the world list contains players from a wide variety of regions. Countries with multiple players on the list are Italy, Spain, Argentina, France, Brazil, Germany, and Chile. http://uk.businessinsider.com/the-best-footballers-in-the-world-ronaldo-messi-neymar-2017-8/#arturo-vidal-bayern-munich-midfielder-24
Whilst this is a good indication of which nations will have the star players playing for them, its importance should not be overstated. Trophies are won by teams, not by individual players. Precedent The relevance of precedent is in ascertaining the circumstances under which teams typically win the World Cup. 
In the past twenty years, France, Brazil, Italy, Spain and Germany have each won one World Cup.
Nations tend not to win the world cup multiple times in a row, suggesting that Germany winning in 2014 makes it unlikely that they will win again so soon; however, pundits discussing the 2014 World Cup felt that it might mark the beginning of an era of German dominance in football. http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28287042  Giant Killings In sport, giant killings refer to underdogs exceeding expectations and defeating stronger, more established teams in a tournament. The sorts of giant killings relevant to this question would be instances of underdogs winning the world cup, rather than nations making it further than expected but not winning. 
A quick glance at World Cup winners reveals that giant killings of this nature of thoroughly rare and indeed unprecedented in this competition. France, Brazil, Italy, Spain and Germany winning in the past 20 years is exactly what you’d expect. Recent Performance Nations are commonly ranked according to the strength of their football team and these rankings provide key information regarding the dominance of various teams.
In the 2010 and 2014 tournaments, first, second and third place were all awarded to teams in with a top 5 Elo rating that year. This is a strong indicator that the winning team in 2018 will be a team ranked in the top 5 now. As of today, the Elo top 5 are (in order): Brazil, Germany, Spain, Portugal, and France. Thus, these nations should be assigned a higher % chance. 
Recent performance in other competitions is also an indicator of a team’s current strength. Portugal won the most recent Euros, beating France, whilst the 2016 Copa America was won by Chile against finalists Argentina. Successes in these tournaments suggest that the finalists are in a strong position to also dominate at the world cup this year.  The Group Stages Sometimes strong teams are unlucky and get assigned a tough group in the group stages; however, I feel that this year’s groups are relatively balanced, with strong teams spread across all 8 groups. http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/schedule/group-stage Reviewing my Forecast I have three reviews planned.
1.	I will review my forecast just before the tournament begins to accommodate for key players being injured and other relevant developments.
2.	After the group stages, I will be able to rule out any teams that have been knocked out already. 
3.	Before the final I will be able to undertake an in-depth analysis of the two finalists, based on their performances throughout the tournament.

The establishment of football world rankings goes back to 1993. Since that time, the winners and runners of each world cup has been as follows, with world cup rankings from the previous year in brackets:
1994 - Brazil (3); Italy (2)
1998 - France (7); Brazil (1)
2002 - Brazil (3); Germany (12)
2006 - Italy (12); France (5)
2010 - Spain (2); Netherlands (3)
2014 - Germany (2); Argentina (3)
It does therefore seem that the winner is almost certain to come from the top 15. We can also see that former winners do tend to reach the final stages - Brazil, Argentina, Germany and Italy were all previous winners. Nevertheless, for a sport that has a relatively small number of countries that have ever won, it does seem that the Spanish and French victories shows that it is not an unthinkable for a team that has never won to succeed. I think there is a risk of overstating the home-nation effect: both Brazil and Germany failed to win in 2014 and 2006 respectively when they might have been expected to have had a good chance. On the basis of the groups, you would expect the following teams to progress:
A - Russia & Uruguay; B - Portugal & Spain; C - France & either Denmark or Peru; D - Argentina and Croatia; E - Brazil & Switzerland; F - Germany and 1 of SK, MX or SW; G - Belgium & England; H - 2 of Colombia, Japan and Poland. I will disregard any other teams, who might fluke a couple of rounds but will eventually get beaten by a stronger side. Of those teams mentioned above, those currently in the top 10 rankings are (in order): Germany, Brazil, Portugal, Argentina, Belgium, Spain, Poland, Switzerland, France. My mathematical breakdown will therefore be as follows. Base rate of 10% for any likely round of 16 team in the top 10 rankings. Minus 3, for any non-recent winner (i.e. not Germany, Brazil, France, Spain). Bonuses for top team's rankings (10 for Germany, 5 for Brazil, 2 for Portugal, Argentina and Belgium). 4% chance of a team outside of top 10 winning. I will correct as we get more information on team's form etc.

Bleacher reports's World Cup team rankings (linked below) list Germany, Brazil, Spain, and France as the top four in descending order.  Hard to argue with that, and very unlikely that the winner won't be one of those four, though three other teams (Argentina, Belgium, and Uruguay) could rise to the occasion.  On the global stage of the World Cup, the competition is usually too fierce, and pressure too intense, for third-tier teams with only one or two world-class stars (Portugal, England, Poland) to advance to the finals.
